title: US and allies intensify efforts to reduce energy reliance on Russia
text:
Good evening

Today's announcement that the US would increase supplies of liquefied natural gas to Europe is the latest proposal to help wean the west off its dependence on Russian energy.

The additional 15bn cubic metres of LNG, some from the US itself and some from swaps arranged with other countries, would, president Joe Biden insisted, “increase energy security, economic security and national security”. He added: “I know that eliminating Russian gas will have costs for Europe. But it's not only the right thing to do from a moral standpoint, it's going to put us on a much stronger strategic footing.”

Germany said it would wean itself off Russian gas by mid-2024 as well as becoming “virtually independent” of Russian oil by the end of this year, although chancellor Olaf Scholz earlier this week stood firm against an immediate ban on Russian fossil fuels, warning it would trigger a recession. More than half of the gas and coal that it imports come from Russia, as does a third of its oil.

The issue of soaring energy prices is also rapidly moving up domestic policy agendas. The German government yesterday set out a €16bn package of aid to counter soaring costs, while UK chancellor Rishi Sunak hinted at more help for consumers in the autumn after being pilloried for doing little to help struggling families in Wednesday's Spring Statement.

Governments are also scrambling to diversify and ramp up efforts in sustainable energy. UK prime minister Boris Johnson said on Monday he wanted to deliver new nuclear power stations at “warp speed” with the aim of providing at least a quarter of electricity generation by 2050.

Johnson hopes to publish a new energy supply strategy next week which would remove the need for Russian oil and gas and reduce the UK's exposure to volatile commodity markets. He is also keen to increase output from the North Sea, a move that has attracted criticism from climate campaigners, although he said it would not derail efforts to cut net carbon emissions to zero by 2050. Global moves to revive coal mining have attracted similar ire from campaigners.

Removing supplies of Russian oil into Europe would lead to a lasting reshaping of global energy markets. Oil traders warned this week that the price of crude could top $200 a barrel this year if boycotts gather pace while alternative sources are yet to solidify, and central banks are unlikely to offer immediate support to ease strains in the market.

Commercial relationships will also be difficult to disentangle. Our Big Read examines BP's 32-year partnership with Russia and how it defined the west's “lucrative yet complicated courtship” of the post-Soviet country.

The exit of the oil majors, writes energy correspondent Tom Wilson, “mark the end of an era — ‘a complete geopolitical reset' . . . that could cut off much of the world from Russian resources, business and culture for a generation.” 

As you will have noticed, our Road to Recovery newsletter has changed to Disrupted Times to reflect the impact of the Ukraine crisis, as well as the pandemic, on global business and economies. We'll continue to bring you the best FT journalism highlighting the latest news and trends three times a week, including workplace issues on Mondays and Wednesdays and a round-up of the latest pandemic science on Fridays. As ever, feedback is welcome — email us at disruptedtimes@ft.com.

Need to know: the economy

UK retail sales fell more than expected in February while business and consumer confidence plunged in March as uncertainties around the war in Ukraine added to the effects of the cost-of-living crisis. Businesses in the monthly PMI survey showed increasing concern at the likelihood of “stagflation” — the combination of slow growth and high inflation — in the months ahead.

Latest for the UK/Europe

There was more negative reaction to Rishi Sunak's UK Spring Statement as the Institute for Fiscal Studies and Resolution Foundation think tanks criticised the chancellor's tax-cutting rhetoric when the vast majority of Britons would see their taxes rise. Boris Johnson conceded the government needed to “do more” on the cost-of-living crisis. Our personal finance team examines what Sunak's plans mean for investors and householders.

The Bank of England postponed its annual stress tests on banks because of uncertainties thrown up by the war. The BoE said British banks' direct exposure to Russia was only about 1 per cent of their highest quality equity, meaning they could easily write off the total and still meet minimum capital requirements.

PMI results for the eurozone showed companies reporting a record surge in costs and selling prices since Russia's invasion. Economists expect the war and the sanctions the west has imposed on Moscow to reduce growth and drive up inflation.

Global latest

BlackRock chief executive Larry Fink warned the Ukraine war had “put an end to the globalisation we have experienced over the last three decades” as companies and governments examine their dependencies on other countries and attempt to onshore or nearshore more of their operations. Howard Marks of Oaktree Capital Management echoed the sentiments in an article for the FT, arguing that “choosing to rely on a hostile neighbour for essential goods is like building a bank vault and contracting the mob to supply it with guards”.

Egypt asked for IMF support as surging oil and grain prices hit the country's economy, already suffering from a collapse in tourism from Russia. Egypt is the world's biggest wheat importer, heavily reliant on supplies from Russia and Ukraine, and has a subsidised bread programme which feeds 70mn people.

Global bond markets are in their deepest downturn for decades as investors brace for rapid rises in interest rates as central banks battle against inflation, even at the risk of choking off recovery. The US government bond market is having its worst month since Donald Trump was elected president in 2016.

Damage from the Ukraine conflict is spreading to the developing world with prospects growing of a damaging sovereign debt crisis, write William Rhodes and John Lipsky of the Sovereign Debt Working Group of the Bretton Woods Committee.

New central bank moves included rises in rates in South Africa and Mexico, where the country's president let slip the details hours ahead of the official announcement.

Need to know: business

The UK put fresh sanctions on Russian companies and individuals including Mikhail Fridman's Alfa-Bank, the Kremlin-linked Wagner Group of mercenaries and Herman Gref, head of Russia's largest bank, Sberbank. Roman Abramovich's yachts meanwhile are seeking a haven in Turkey.

Hedge funds have been gathering up battered Russian and Ukrainian bonds after the crisis led to many traditional investors exiting the market. Moscow's stock market reopened after being shut for three weeks. Moody's followed S&P Global and Fitch in withdrawing credit ratings for Russian entities.

The FT revealed Geely was considering its future in Russia, casting doubt on the idea that Chinese carmakers would rush to take advantage of gaps left by international rivals such as Renault, VW and Toyota as they halt sales in the country, the third-largest market for Beijing auto exports after Chile and Saudi Arabia.

Lloyd's of London, the specialist market for insurance and reinsurance, said it expected “multibillion-dollar losses” from the Ukraine crisis but was confident they would be manageable and that some predictions for exposure were “too magnificent”. The Lex column agreed Lloyds appeared to be well covered from usual sources of disasters, but cautioned that state-orchestrated cyber attacks could leave insurers vulnerable to claims.

Factories in China are setting up isolated “bubbles” for its workforces so they can continue working during tough new coronavirus lockdowns. The country is experiencing its biggest Covid-19 outbreak for more than two years, with tens of millions of people forced to stay at home.

Apple and Google hit back at new EU measures that will force a radical overhaul of their global operations. Here's our Big Read on the new Digital Markets Act.

US delivery company Instacart said it would build micro-warehouses to fend off threats from newer delivery apps and Amazon's growing presence in groceries. “Sign of the times” UK retail stories included Next noticing a “very sharp reversal of lockdown fashion trends” as shoppers returned to formal wear and a continuance of the DIY boom that accelerated during the pandemic, evidenced in strong profits from Kingfisher, owner of B&Q and Screwfix.

Science round up

The World Health Organization said Europe was experiencing a new surge in infections after “brutally” sweeping away coronavirus restrictions. Experts warned the BA.2 subvariant of Omicron was likely to hit the US within weeks.

The UK limited its provision of free lateral flow test kits earlier than expected to discourage the public from competing with at-risk groups for limited supplies. New data today showed UK infections jumped by a million in the week ending March 19.

Scientists are debating the merits of a fourth vaccine dose as Omicron cases continue to rise. There is general agreement for the elderly and those with health problems but less so for younger, healthy people.

Moderna said it would seek emergency use authorisation for its vaccine for children under the age of 6 in the US and EU after interim trial results showed the jab was safe and produced a positive immune response. The child-sized dose — about a quarter the size of an adult's — was only however modestly effective against Omicron.

Global pharma correspondent Hannah Kuchler in her Big Read looks at the potential for artificial intelligence in the search for new drugs after its successful use during the pandemic. Its advocates argue it is part of a revolution in drug discovery that will combine growth in biological and chemical data with computing power to reduce healthcare bills and create treatments for conditions where there are none.

And finally...

The temporary loss of taste or smell experienced by many with Covid-19 has shone a fresh light on our relationship with food. But culinary enjoyment is less about the tongue than the brain, writes restaurant critic Tim Hayward, as he delves into the psychology of taste.
